Award.AwardTitle: Maintaining Relationships with Chronically Insecure Partners: Interpersonal Security Regulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A common assumption made by scientists who study close relationships is that people who have chronic insecurities about interpersonal acceptance tend to undermine their close relationships by engaging in destructive behaviors (e.g., criticism, hostility), which eventually elicit rejection by their partners. A limitation of this view is that it ignores how partners of people with chronic insecurities can actively improve and maintain their relationships with insecure individuals. Dr. Edward Lemay (University of New Hampshire) proposes and tests a model regarding how partners may shape insecure individuals thoughts and feelings about interpersonal acceptance, as well as the effects of insecure individuals on their partners
own thoughts, feelings, and behavior.

Five studies will test the model using a combination of methods, including laboratory manipulations, longitudinal designs, behavioral observation studies, and reaction time measures. The studies answer several important questions: (a) How does having an insecure relationship partner affect attention to and memory for the partner's behavior? (b) What motivations do people have when they interact with an insecure partner? (c) What behaviors do people enact during such interactions? (d) Are people's efforts to make their insecure partners feel valued usually successful? (e) Do people's special efforts to make insecure partners feel accepted and valued predict long-term quality and survival of relationships? The studies also examine whether these processes depend on other relationship factors, such as the degree to which the partner feels dependent on the insecure individual, and the partner's cognitive abilities, such as their ability to control impulses and their memory functioning. Answers to such questions will represent important insights into the relationship dynamics that occur when one partner tends to be insecure about interpersonal acceptance. This includes the active role of partners in contributing to such relationships and the consequences of interpersonal insecurity for a partners psychological functioning.

With regard to broader impacts, the project will provide valuable training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. In addition, new measures of the main study variables will be further developed during the course of this project, which will be available for other researchers who are interested in studying interpersonal relationships. Finally, improved knowledge of the relationship dynamics associated with chronic insecurity has implications for a variety of important social issues including divorce, mental health (e.g., the mental health consequences of chronic insecurity), and the degree to which being in a close relationship is good for people's physical well-being. Finally, this work could have important implications for how to help people have happier relationships in that it will help identify what kinds of "supportive" behaviors are likely to be helpful when one has a chronically insecure partner and what kinds of supportive behaviors may yield little or no relationship benefits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The current project was designed to test a novel theoretical model regarding how people can improve the psychological well-being of relationship partners who tend to have concerns about whether they are valued and cared for by others (such as people who are low in self-esteem and people who are high in attachment anxiety), and people who have difficulty controlling their emotions. This is particularly important because these variables have been associated with personal and interpersonal problems in prior research. A set of experimental studies suggested that people who learn that their relationship partners are insecure tend to adopt goals to make those partners feel more valued and become attentive to information about their partners that could help them achieve those goals, such as information regarding the exact nature of the partner's insecurities and sources of the partner's emotional distress. In turn, people try to satisfy these goals by expressing positive regard for their partner (i.e., evaluating their partner favorably in areas that are important to their partner). In turn, expressing positive regard for the partner helps insecure partners feel more valued and satisfied in the relationship. These studies were conducted using a rigorous "causal chain" approach that improves upon typical correlational methods. In this approach, every path in the model was tested using experimental methods to verify that the links between the model variables were indeed causal. This research extends theorizing on the role of personality in interpersonal relationships by suggesting that relationship partners can help people with proclivities for interpersonal problems, and the current results point to opportunities for developing interventions that involve relationship partners.

The current project also included a longitudinal study to examine how relationships change over time. Results provided strong support for the initial predictions. The results suggested that participants who had anxious attachment (i.e, worries about interpersonal relationships, fears of abandonment) tended to express their insecurities to their relationship partners, which motivated their partners to adopt goals to make those partners feel more valued and enact several prosocial behaviors (e.g., providing support to their partner). These responses were associated with anxiously attached participants' decreases in attachment anxiety and increases in relationship satisfaction over the course of the year. Once again, these findings suggest that relationship partners can help people who have proclivities for interpersonal problems, and suggests the utility of relationship interventions to reduce the destructiveness of particular personality traits.

Studies supported from the current project have been published in several peer-reviewed academic journals, and other manuscripts are currently under review. In addition, findings have been disseminated in conference presentations and on Anxiety.org, a website dedicated to informing the public about issues related to anxiety. This project also provided research training and publications for several undergraduate and graduate students.
